newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain six-mth bills seen starting 97 at record low.
newsitem.headline: Spain six-mth bills seen starting 97 at record low.

text.p: Spain's six-month Treasury bill yields are set to start the new year with a record low, dealers said on Tuesday.
They forecast that at the first auction for 1997 on Thursday, the bill's yield should decline to around 5.90/91 percent from the previous rate of 5.949 pct on December 18.
Market expectations of further reductions in the key money market rate should push yields a little down, boosting total demand.
"There are expectations of new cuts in the rates, and I think we could see them at the auction," said Carmen Hernansanz, economist at Merrill Lynch in Madrid.
The bills were trading on the grey market on Tuesday morning at around 5.88/5.90 percent.

"I expect something similar to the last auctions. The Treasury will sell a high percentage with very good demand, with a marginal yield at around the grey market rate," said Juan Antonio Mielgo, economist at Bank of America here.
On December 13 the Bank of Spain cut its key money market rate by 50 basis points to 6.25 percent, prompted by benign November inflation data.
November CPI was unchanged on the month for a 3.2 percent year-on-year rise versus 3.5 percent in October.
